Literature and Art
6. Practical Philosophy

There is, according to Gadamer, a continuity between a hermeneutics
‘that is aware of its philosophic implications’ and ‘the great
tradition of practical philosophy’ (Gadamer, 2007, p.245), and such a
claim would already seem to be implicit in the idea that
interpretation and application are tied together through the
embeddedness of interpretation in the hermeneutical situation. Gadamer
has himself engaged, however, in direct reflection on a range of
concrete contemporary issues (see Gadamer 1976a, 1989a, 1993b, 1998b,
1999, 2001, see also Krajewski 2003). Gadamer’s discussion of
these issues draws directly upon his more theoretical discussions of
hermeneutics elsewhere, sometimes serving to provide further
elaboration and illumination of the ideas at work in those
discussions. A central concern in many of Gadamer’s essays is
the role of Europe, and European culture, in the contemporary
world—something that was especially pressing for Gadamer with
the advent of German reunification and the expansion of the European
community (see especially Gadamer 1989a). Here, however, a number of
other closely connected issues also come into view: the nature and
role of modern science and technology (see especially 1976a, 1998b),
and together with this, the role of the humanities; the question of
education and, in particular, of humanistic education (1992); the
issue of understanding between cultures, and especially between
religions, and the issue of world literature (see especially George
2020).  In addition, Gadamer has written on matters concerning law,
ethics, the changing character of the modern university, the
connection between philosophy and politics, and the nature of medical
practice and the concept of health (see especially Gadamer 1993b, see
also see Aho 2022).

In almost all of these areas, Gadamer’s approach is
characterized, not by the attempt to apply pre-existing theory to the
domain in question, but rather by the attempt to think from within
that domain, and in a way that is attentive to it, that also entails a
reciprocity between the theoretical and the applied. As Gadamer
comments in Truth and Method, ‘application is neither a
subsequent nor merely an occasional part of the phenomenon of
understanding, but co-determines it as a whole from the
beginning’ (Gadamer 1989b, 324). Theory and application do not
occur, then, in separation from one another, but are part of a single
hermeneutical ‘practice’. The interdependence of
philosophical theory and practical application, often in the form of
an interdependence between theoretical engagement in one domain and
engagement in another, is evident to a degree in some of the very
early responses to Gadamer’s work by thinkers from outside of
philosophy who had interests in the implications of hermeneutic
thinking within their own specific domains. Thus Gadamer’s work
was famously taken up in the 1960s by the Italian jurist Emilio Betti
(see Betti, 2021[1964], pp. 45–61), and Betti’s work was also
drawn upon by E. D. Hirsch whose concerns came from the direction of
literary theory (see Hirsch, 1965, 1967). Theology was another area
where Gadamer had an early impact (see eg. Robinson. and Cobb, 1964),
partly reinforced through connections between his work and that of the
theologian Bernard Lonergan (see Lawrence, 1984).

Gadamer’s thinking has continued to be influential in legal
theory and jurisprudence (see Mootz 2007), in literary theory (see
Weinsheimer, 1991), and theology (see Lawrence, 2006), but the
interconnection of philosophical and practical hermeneutics that is
evident in Gadamer’s own work has itself been reflected in the
way that work has been taken up in relation to practical and applied
issues within many other domains—within, for instance, health
and medical practice (see e.g., Svenaueus 2003), intercultural studies
(see e.g., Garfield 2002, Lammi 2008)), education (see e.g., Fairfield
2012), environmental education and ecology (see e.g., Grün
2005),architecture (see e.g. Snodgrass and Coyne 2006), and political
theory (see e.g. Walhof, 2022)(on many of these topics, see also the
various chapters in Malpas & Gander 2014). Gadamer’s work
has also seen application, though not uncontentiously, within feminism
(see Homan, 2022) and contemporary race theory (Botts, 2022).

That practical engagement is an essential element in Gadamer’s
thinking implies that it cannot be seen to stand aside from questions
of ethics. Gadamer never developed a book-length treatment that
addresses such questions, but there is clearly an ethical current that
runs throughout his thinking, and that is discernible, for instance,
in his emphasis on the conversational character of hermeneutic
engagement as well as his later reflections on the relation to the
other (including on themes of friendship and solidarity) (see Gadamer
1999). It is also clearly evident in the engagement with Aristotle
that runs throughout Gadamer’s work as well as his engagement
with Plato (notably Gadamer, 1991). Despite the absence of a fully
developed account, Gadamer has addressed the matter of ethics directly
in, most notably, ‘On the Possibility of a Philosophical
Ethics’ (Gadamer, 1999, pp. 18–36 and 2007, pp. 274–289), in which
Gadamer argues against Kantian formalism in favor of a more
Aristotelian approach. The issue of the ethical dimension in
Gadamer’s thought and in hermeneutics more generally has also
been taken up in the work of others (see especially Schmidt, 2015;
George, 2020).
